instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to classify rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds?
Output: The related study used THz spectrum to classify rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to classify rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to classify rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds were the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) and the one-vs-rest implementation of the support vector machine with both linear kernel and radial basis kernel function (OVR(SVM-linear) and OVR(SVM RBF)) classifiers.

instruction: What metric was chosen to classify rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds, and how far can this metric go in terms of accuracy?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning classifiers in classifying rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds in the THz region was accuracy. The accuracy of the classifiers ranged from 88% to 99% for simulated spectra. In terms of accuracy, the classifiers achieved average classification accuracies of 87% to 94% for the experimental dataset.

instruction: What were the results of using the support vector machine (SVM) classifier with linear and radial basis function kernels, as well as the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) classifier, in classifying rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds in the THz region?
Output:
The results of using the support vector machine (SVM) classifier with linear and radial basis function kernels, as well as the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) classifier, in classifying rotational absorption spectra for gas-phase compounds in the THz region were as follows:

- The one-versus-rest (OVR) implementation of the SVM classifier with linear and radial basis function kernels achieved average classification accuracies of 87-94% for the experimental dataset.
- The MLP classifier, implemented in both standard and OVR implementations, also achieved average classification accuracies of 87-94% for the experimental dataset.

These results indicate that both the SVM classifier with linear and radial basis function kernels and the MLP classifier were effective in classifying the rotational absorption spectra for the gas-phase compounds in the THz region, with accuracies ranging from 87% to 94%.

instruction: Can the machine learning methods implemented in the related study using rotational absorption spectra in the THz region be applied to other frequency ranges, compounds, and conditions for gas sensing applications?
Output: Yes, the machine learning methods implemented in the related study using rotational absorption spectra in the THz region can be applied to other frequency ranges, compounds, and conditions for gas sensing applications. The study suggests that the THz spectra in the frequency range of 220-330 GHz provide a sufficient spectral fingerprint for the machine learning classifiers to learn and predict speciation. Therefore, it is possible to extrapolate these methods to different frequency ranges and compounds, as well as different conditions, for automated gas sensing.
